Furthermore, for what meaning is this parable spoken? Not for frivolous speech, not for
untimely [speech].
Why is it so?
In order to greatly expand the profound meaning of the Buddha's teachings;
In order to reveal the principle of dependent origination, various extensive parables are made.
The king's city refers to the three realms of existence.

Within the city of the three realms of existence, there are birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, dejection, and despair; the suffering of separation from what is loved, the suffering of not obtaining what one seeks, the suffering of encountering what is disliked, slander, bad reputation, upholding precepts, breaking precepts, and so forth - various kinds of immeasurable suffering are beyond calculation.
Afflictions, calamities, and epidemics result in the loss of wholesome roots.
Bodhisattvas, out of compassion, are like a mother cow thinking of her calf, and for sentient beings, they become true friends, making firm vows, being courageous and valiant, and rescuing all.

They skillfully understand the causes and effects of the bonds of birth and death, and are well able to understand the Dharma and what is not the Dharma, and are endowed with the four means of embracing and accomplishing the One Vehicle.

Great-minded beings observe that the five realms revolve and undergo suffering, always being harmed by the four great poisonous snakes, the five aggregates of enemies and thieves, the six sense bases that are like an empty village, the foolish five desires that are deceptively kind, and the self and what belongs to the self.
These beings are bound by afflictions. How can I now not rescue them?

After the Bodhisattva had contemplated such matters, he rose from his palace and left home. He donned the armor of diligence, protected himself with the divine spells of the four means of embracing, anointed his body with the good medicine of mindfulness of the body, used the merit of patience as his weapons and armor, and used the wisdom cultivated over innumerable eons as his sharp sword, and single-mindedly contemplated the royal highway.
When sitting in the place of enlightenment, he observed the source of suffering in the entire world and made a great vow to definitely uproot it.

The root of this suffering is to oppress sentient beings with great suffering and distress, to be the foremost of many afflictions, and to be covered by the ninety-six kinds of foolishness, not recognizing the source of the afflictions of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, with right contemplation, saw the immeasurable suffering and affliction of old age, sickness, and death.
Having understood this meaning, he immediately asked Old Age:
What is your name?
Old Age replied:
My name is Old Age.
The Bodhisattva asked:
What do you age?
Old Age replied:
As for my aging, I can age the three realms.
The Bodhisattva asked:
What else do you do?
Old Age replied:
I do nothing.
The Bodhisattva said:
You bring hunger and famine to those you love.
Your thoughts are like wild elephants trampling a grove of plantains, crushing everything.
You are the wilderness, the distant and dangerous road, able to destroy the pleasure of the six senses;
Able to destroy youthful appearance, like hail damaging flowers, and shifting away vigorous strength;
Able to cause the six senses to be exhausted and dried up.
How can you say:
I do nothing!
The old one replied:
This is indeed true.
The Bodhisattva said:
The two words 'old age' are heard throughout the three realms, but no one understands their meaning.
The old one said again:
You now truly understand me to the end.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Who is the second one?
The old one replied:
It is called death.
At that time, the Bodhisattva immediately asked Death:
What a coarse and evil name you have!
Death replied:
Not only is the name evil, but the matter under the name is even more coarse and evil.
I can kill all the humans, gods, asuras, yakshas, and ghosts in all worlds.
Just as a great rakshasa can destroy a country, I can also destroy the lives of all beings.
The Bodhisattva asked:
How strange!
You are the most evil,
lacking any compassion.
Wherever you roam, there is no place you do not reach. Your lowly evil karma is worse than yours.
Death replied:
This is indeed my nature.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Although your nature is like this, with the power of my mind, I will definitely end you.
Although you are difficult to subdue, with my diligence, I will definitely subdue you.
Just as the waves of the ocean cannot blow the mountain, how can you kill me?
Death replied:
Although you have this intention now, I'm afraid you won't be able to control me.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Why do you now doubt that I am incapable?
Death replied:
If there is diligence and skillful means, then one can subdue me.
I fear that you may not be courageous and diligent, and therefore I doubt you.
The Bodhisattva said:
You should observe me, with compassion and skillful means for immeasurable eons.
Using my own life to replace that of sentient beings, even for a great enemy, if they were to use a sharp sword to sever my limbs, I would always give rise to a compassionate mind towards them;
If sentient beings in urgent danger come to me, I would rather give up my life to rescue and protect them.
Are such skillful means enough to extinguish you?
Death replied:
What need is there to speak much and go back and forth? What is the point of exhausting yourself and afflicting me?
I shall sincerely tell you the root, and this root is precisely birth.

Birth gives rise to immeasurable suffering and distress in all worlds. The four great poisonous snakes, the five aggregates of enemies, the six sense faculties, and the cycle of the five paths are all created by birth.
This birth initially gives rise to all suffering, let alone the middle and later stages;
If one accepts birth, the suffering is immeasurable. If one abandons birth, then there are no faults.
All faults arise from birth. It is like this: without firewood, fire has nothing to burn;
Also, without a tree, an axe has nothing to chop;ğŸ”½Also, without a pot, what does a hammer break?
Like without lotus flowers, frost has nothing to destroy;
Using this analogy, one knows that birth has many faults.
If you now sincerely and decisively vow to end death, you must first end birth.
Because of this birth, there are old age, sickness, death, worry, sorrow, suffering, distress, and various calamities and afflictions, all of which have power.
The Bodhisattva said:
I understand this matter. If there is a mountain, the vajra will definitely destroy it.
If there is no mountain, even if the vajra is hard, what can it destroy?
All those who have a body will definitely have suffering. If there is no body, what suffering is there to suffer?
At that time, the Bodhisattva let go of old age and death, and grasped at birth.
He asked:
What is your name?
Birth replied:
I have many different names, but the most supreme among them is called birth.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Why is it called birth?
Birth replied:
You should observe it yourself.
The Bodhisattva then observed birth and said:
This birth produces all existences, coming from the combination of two characters to form the meaning of birth.
Birth replied:
Your wisdom now is truly not upside down. You understand it through reasoning.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Since this birth gives rise to all suffering, why is it not called 'the emergence of all suffering,' but rather 'birth'?
Birth replied:
I have this fault, it is truly as you say.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Do you not see that I have a firm vow that can cut you off?
I take compassion as my essence and can extinguish all the sufferings of the world.
Birth replied:
Excellent, excellent!
It is truly as you say, I am not independent, I exist depending on others.
All men who obtain this power can give rise to the suffering of all birth and death.
If you do not believe, why not observe yourself?
The Bodhisattva thought:
I now observe birth, I definitely know it exists.
And these three existences are the three great dragons, able to rain down torrential rain into the river of birth, entering the sea of death;
There is a river of causes and conditions, which sweeps away sentient beings and drowns them in the sea of suffering.
At that time, the Bodhisattva immediately abandoned birth and grasped at existence, reprimanding existence, saying:
I am the true savior for all sentient beings, wielding the sword of wisdom, able to slay the enemy!
How dare you now, recklessly indulging in adornments, to manifest birth?
Existence then replied:
The hook of the four graspings pulls me along.
Attached to existence, the four powerful graspings capture the foolish.
It said:
I will enjoy giving to existence. How can you, who only increase suffering, give to existence?
The graspings replied:
Just as space cannot produce a tree, but with the causes and conditions of earth and water, a tree can be produced. If there is no water of craving, how can a tree of existence be born?
You should not just reprimand me!
The Bodhisattva then abandoned the four graspings and grasped at craving.
MaitrÄ«pÄla Bodhisattva said:
Welcome, Prince of Åšuddhodana!
For immeasurable eons, you have cultivated various merits and accumulated wholesome practices.
Your power surpasses that of Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra and MahÄ-BrahmÄ. You should focus your attention and accept my small offerings.
The Bodhisattva asked:
What offerings do you have?
MaitrÄ«pÄla replied:
The five desires and pleasures experienced through the five sense faculties are my offerings.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Why use these five sense faculties to invite me?
MaitrÄ«pÄla replied:
I invite you with form, smell, taste, and touch.
The Bodhisattva said:
Are you now inviting me with fragrant and delicious poisonous fruits?
MaitrÄ«pÄla replied:
Why call them poisonous?
The Bodhisattva said:ğŸ”½What is the use of these five sense faculties?
These five desires are like throwing a sheep into a fire, and also like a blind person falling into a deep pit, going against liberation and closing the door to nirvana.
A wise person should avoid the five desires even in dreams, let alone when awake!
Ai replied:
Are the five desires of the gods not excellent?
The Bodhisattva said:
They are also like illusions and dreams.

There was a celestial maiden named Sundari who was as beautiful as the sun, riding in a celestial palace, enjoying music at will, but when her blessings were exhausted and her life ended, she fell back into hell. Isn't this deception!
Ai replied:
If you now dislike the affairs of the desire realm, are not the pleasures of the gods in the form realm excellent?
In the form realm, they abide in meditation and have few faults.
The Bodhisattva said:
I know all about the sufferings and afflictions in the form realm.
Ai replied:
How can you now observe and know this?
The Bodhisattva said:
Although one may attain dhyÄna concentration and be reborn in the Brahma world, when one's blessings are exhausted and one's life ends, one falls into the three evil paths.
It is like burning and then cooling with water, sentient beings with little blessings revolve and suffer.
Love replied:
As you understand, the highest is the peak of existence. Your mind is contemptible, the same as grass.
The Bodhisattva asked:
What is called the peak of existence?
Love replied:
The four formless realms are called the peak of existence.
The Bodhisattva asked:
What is the essence and characteristic of the four formless realms?
Love replied:
In those formless realms, the devas can definitely live for eighty thousand great eons.
The Bodhisattva asked:
When those great eons end, what else do they undergo?
Love replied:
When the eighty thousand eons end, that is called the end.
The Bodhisattva said:ğŸ”½Alas!
Strange!
Contemplate the immeasurable suffering and distress in the desire realm, observe that the essence of the form realm is bound to perish, and even in the four formless realms one does not escape death.
In the world, happiness is little and suffering is much, which is greatly lamentable!
Love replied:
If you now wish to leave my realm, where else do you seek happiness?
The Bodhisattva asked:
Where is your realm?
Love replied:
All conditioned things are my realm.
The Bodhisattva said:
Death reigns supreme over all conditioned things, which is your realm.
I now transcend the realm of conditioned things, where death does not reach and one is forever free from the place of death;

where there is no love, separation, resentment, or gathering, no birth, old age, sickness, sorrow, or distress, where the five aggregates are exhausted, the five faculties cease, and all faculties are of no use, where the omniscient one praises the emergence of ambrosia.
How could such a place not be considered beyond your realm?
Having heard this, Kamadeva laughed loudly and said:
There are countless great sages like Vishvamitra and Baradvaja who have all made such claims, but none have been seen to succeed.
The Bodhisattva said:
Although they wish to seek it, they do not know the means.
Kamadeva replied:
What means do you have now?
The Bodhisattva said:
You should now abandon deceiving sentient beings and all your great arrogance.
I will now pull you out, just as a great elephant pulls out a small plant.
Kamadeva replied:
Excellent!
Great-minded being!
I rely on sensation, so I should first grasp sensation.
The Bodhisattva said:
I now contemplate that all beings fear the essence and characteristics of suffering.
The faculties run wild, yearning for pleasure, but pleasure is not self-controlled, it exists due to others, and pleasure is a deceptive, temporarily existing phenomenon.
Foolish people, though they often obtain pleasure, are never satisfied.
Pleasure is heedless and can rob the faculties, deceiving the human mind, causing ordinary people to fall like flies into honey, obtaining very little taste but losing much.
Not distinguishing between good and bad, seeing and giving rise to love, like pouring ghee and oil into a great fire, the blazing flames double.
Love, stay for a while, wait for me to capture and accept you, then I will punish you.
You and acceptance are equally at fault, both of you should be punished.
Love replied:
Prince of the ÅšÄkyas!
Although you are strong and have this intention, you fear you cannot restrain me.
Why is that?

In the past, at the beginning of the eon, there were great sages such as Kapila who appeared in a good time with a lifespan of 80,000 years, and their virtue and conduct were profound and abundant, yet they still could not harm me, let alone you in the evil age at the end of the eon with a short lifespan not even reaching 100 years.
The Bodhisattva said:
Have I appeared in an evil age?
Love said:
Indeed, you have appeared in an evil age.
The Bodhisattva said:
Even if afflictions are rampant and I have appeared in a turbulent time, if I do not break through your door of ignorance, how can I be called a great man?
Love said:
Stop!
Do not praise yourself.
The Bodhisattva said:
I speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.
This is the right time and place, and I speak the truth with meaning.
Just as the light of the newly risen sun cannot be hidden, the light of wisdom of a great man is also difficult to conceal.
Love replied:
Observing your resolve, although you are courageous and diligent, I have yet to see your accomplishment.
You repeatedly praise yourself, like a peacock rejoicing when clouds and thunder bring heavy rain.
But now you have only brought forth clouds and thunder, I have yet to see the rain, so what benefit is there in this dry thunder?
Judging by your thoughts, I fear you are without substance.
The Bodhisattva said:
I will now show you the truth.
The good deeds I have accumulated over immeasurable eons, with a single-minded intention and the sharp sword of wisdom, I will use to cut you down.
Love replied:
What is the sudden?
The Bodhisattva said again:
Who is it that creates the cause of disturbance for me and sings this song?
Who is it whose hands of karmic afflictions touch the three-realm lute and disturb all deceitful beings?
Love said:
I am the one who guides such singing and wants to play the lute. This is my original intention.
I am now doing what he does and being employed by him.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Is this craving?
Craving replied:
Yes.
The Bodhisattva said:
Craving is the greatest fire, able to burn all kinds of things everywhere.
Those who are attached to pleasure all fall into craving, like foolish infants falling into it like moths to a flame.
Craving said:
Observe thoroughly.
The Bodhisattva said:
I understand this. Those who crave the pleasures of birth and death will surely be harmed by craving;
Those who enjoy flavors like birds and beasts will surely be covered by nets.
Craving said:
You truly understand this.
However, I am indeed able to cause foolish ordinary beings to become attached to the pleasures of existence, and later their bodies will surely experience severe suffering.
Sentient beings craving the pleasures of existence are my doing, up to being born in the highest heaven, and then causing them to fall back down.
The Bodhisattva said:
You are not speaking falsely.
In the world, there is nothing more thirsty than craving, just as drinking salty water increases thirst even more;
Drinking water with salt increases craving even more.
Craving said:
Do not kill me!
The Bodhisattva said:
Although your words are good, your mind always harbors evil.
If I do not eliminate you, how can I be at ease?
Although it is like this, you may stay for a while, waiting for me to take on the sensations.
The Bodhisattva contemplated:
From what do sensations arise?

He then encouraged himself, his body and mind vigorous, not harboring cowardice, removing all distractions and attaining the feet of tranquil concentration, entering the stage of omniscience, and immediately saw the sensations.
He said to the sensations:
For a long time, you have deceived sentient beings, while I have become an unsolicited close friend for all sentient beings.
From now on, you will no longer be able to create disturbances.
The sensations said:
What disturbances have I created?
The Bodhisattva said:
Those who take on a body have a nature of suffering. They falsely display the appearance of happiness, confusing the minds of ordinary fools.
Although they appear to be kind and good, they are actually great enemies.
The one who accepts said in reply:
There truly are these faults.
However, sentient beings still love and cling to me, like bees collecting flowers, only greedy for their fragrance and flavor, agitated and restless.
The Bodhisattva said:
What you say is true.

For the sake of happiness, people enter the ocean and encounter various difficulties, for the sake of happiness they enter battle formations where arrows are like clouds and rain, swords and spears strike each other,

For the sake of happiness, they travel far on perilous roads, suffering from hunger and thirst in the wilderness, for the sake of happiness they engage in various austerities, throwing themselves into the abyss, leaping into fires, scorching themselves with the five heats, sleeping on thorns, fasting, sitting on rafters, wearing tree bark and grass robes, eating fruits and vegetables.
For the sake of happiness, they create various tools, plow fields and cultivate crops;
Creating dwellings and weaving clothes.
All these things are for the sake of pleasure, and give rise to immeasurable suffering.
The feeling said:
It is indeed so.
But I can make all sentient beings experience immeasurable suffering for the sake of pleasure.
I am extremely fickle and never still for a moment, yet sentient beings are attached to the pleasure they experience, thinking it is always so.
The Bodhisattva said:
All sentient beings are to be pitied, constantly deluded and thirsty by you, yet sentient beings are foolish and dark, disturbed by you.
The feeling said:
My faults are not just limited to this, there are other offenses that are even worse than this.
Since beginningless time, I have been moving and flowing, always swallowed and accepted by all living beings, never being satisfied.
Like oil poured into a fire, the fire is never satisfied. All of them are attached to me, and none can see my faults.
The Bodhisattva said:
Today, by the side of the enemy of love, I will loudly call out, draw the sword of wisdom, and be about to cut it down.
Love said:
It is because of you, not my fault.
If it is really as he says, I will now cut you down.
If you do not exist, then love will not exist either.
The receiver said:
I am not in control, I am controlled by contact. Even if you harm me, it will not benefit you.
The Bodhisattva then explained the sequence, and with his hand of wisdom he stroked contact, and said to contact:
What is your name?
You give rise to suffering for all sentient beings.
Because of you, the feet of birth and death are able to grow, and the door to nirvana is closed.
Contact said:
The one who is able to give rise to feeling, this matter is indeed so.
The reason is that when the three things come together, contact arises as a condition, just as when a person, a fire drill, and a drill are combined, fire can be produced. I am also like this.
When there is the eye, consciousness, and the three things come together, contact arises. Due to the condition of contact, feeling arises.
If there were no six sense bases, how could I arise?
The Bodhisattva said:
You are speaking the truth.
Apart from the three conditions, there is no contact. The stream of contact's arising is closest to the six sense faculties.
Contact, for now, stay!
You must take the six sense faculties and share the same crime with you.
At that time, the Bodhisattva comprehended the characteristics of contact and then investigated the six sense faculties:
These six sense faculties are like a swallow's nest, also like a water bubble, and also like a newly formed boil that will soon burst. What powerful force is there to be so arrogant?
The six sense bases said:
Why do you speak like this?
The Bodhisattva said:
Because of you, you provide power for contact. Since you are yourself without affairs, you recklessly give rise to clinging and produce all suffering.
I end disputes, how could I dispute with you?
The six sense bases said:
My faults are light, I can only give rise to contact.
The Bodhisattva said:
I now observe that the root of contact is due to you.

The six sense bases are a great cave of immeasurable suffering and distress. You are always mad and never tranquil, your intentions are always restless and never well-controlled, and you are never satisfied with what you cling to.
The six sense faculties are foolish and greedy, craving the six contacts and seeking the six sense objects.
